results.title: The Public enemy
results.creator_credit: William Wellman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: James Cagney plays Tom Powers, the son of a Chicago policeman, growing up in the city slums where, as a boy, he naturally turns to petty crime as a way of life. As an adult he becomes a successful big-time liquor racketeer. Tom Power has no socially redeemimg traits. He takes pleasure in even the most petty of physical insults, such as grinding half a grapefruit into the startled face of Mae Clark. Cagney’s raw ferocious portrayal of a vicious criminal is masterful and the film is a classic in its genre. Also stars Jean Harlow and Joan Blondell.

results.title: The Lost boys (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Harvey Bernhard and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This popular 1987 film presents an interesting mix of genres: the 1980s teen movie with vampires. Michael and Sam are two brothers who have moved with their mother to Santa Carla, “murder capitol of the world”, unaware of the vampires residing in this fictional Californian Coastal town (the film was shot in Santa Barbara, and includes spectacular footage of the Boardwalk and beach-side amusement park). Michael is charmed by a girl named Star, and immediately falls in with a tough young gang led by David. It’s peer pressure in the extreme as Michael is tricked into drinking blood. He is turned into an unwilling vampire, and Sam looks to a pair of comic book vendors who are well versed in the dealings with vampires, to help save Michael. The insecurities and frustrations of youth are amplified and satirised by this exciting and funny MTV-generation thriller. Cast includes: Jason Patric, Corey Haim, Dianne Wiest, Kiefer Sutherland and Corey Feldman.

results.title: An Unmarried woman
results.creator_credit: Paul Mazursky, Tony Ray and Fox
results.brief_description: Jill Clayburgh and Alan Bates star in this excellent production depicting the reconstruction of a life, as Clayburgh struggles to find herself after her husband leaves her for another woman. Torn between conflicting forces, her lovers and her daughter, Clayburgh learns to take control of her life. This film became a beacon for the Women’s Movement in the 1970’s.

results.title: A Trip to Mars
results.creator_credit: Ashley Miller and Edison Manufacturing Company
results.brief_description: By mixing two power-like substances, a scientist discovers the source of reverse gravity. When he tries this concoction on himself, he is elevated to the planet Mars. This Edison Manufacturing Company production is reported to be the first science-fiction film produced in the United States.

results.title: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

video_links.name: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

results.brief_description: The 1960s brought on a change in government in Australia, resulting in greater funding towards the arts and Australia’s film industry in particular. In turn, this political change gave rise to what was to be called the ‘Australian New Wave’ in cinema. Celebrated film critic, David Stratton, shares his recollections of this pivotal time with fellow key players: Jan Chapman, Matt Carroll, Paul Cox and Phillip Noyce (via SKYPE). This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.
results.title_for_label: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

results.title: Two thousand women
results.creator_credit: Frank Launder, Edward Black and Gainsborough Pictures
results.brief_description: Phyllis Calvert, Patricia Roc and Flora Robson star in this vivid document of 1944: a time when women were finding a new independence, and women stars and audience were taken seriously by British cinema. This intense story of a prisoner of warcamp in occupied france, takes the classic formulas common to male prison camp drama and transforms them. The women stand up to the enemy, outwit their jailers, help inmates to escape without tears or hysteria. They are mutually supportive in the face of their privations and their story is told through a woman’s eyes rather than from the male perspective

results.title: Death in Brunswick (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John Ruane, Timothy White, Film Victoria, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Meridian Films
results.brief_description: Carl Fitzgerald (Sam Neill) is the hard-luck hero in this pleasant little black comedy set in the Melbourne suburb of Brunswick. Carl lands a chef’s job in the cockroach infested kitchen of a dodgy nightclub. He meets a luscious young barmaid (Zoe Carides) who has the hots for him, but as luck would have it, the rocky romance is headed for trouble when an unfortunate incident at the club embroils Carl in a complicated mess. He enlists the help of his mate Dave (John Clarke)…things can only get worse from here on.

results.title: From Mao to Mozart: Isaac Stern in China
results.creator_credit: Murray Lerner and Harmony Film Group
results.brief_description: Isaac Stern and his family visited China for three weeks in 1989 as the guests of the Foreign Minister. Stern visits schools and conservatories of music, giving master classes and concerts, and speaking to music teachers who lived through the Cultural revolution.

results.title: 'At the movies': Tim Burton masterclass with Margaret Pomeranz
results.brief_description: Hosted by Margaret Pomeranz, this masterclass reveals the workings behind Tim Burton’s creative genius, offering insight into his creative process with a rare view into his world of melancholic misfits, gothic suburbia and contemporary fairytales.

results.title: The Crying game
results.creator_credit: Neil Jordan, Stephen Woolley, Nippon Film Development & Finance, Euro Trustees, Channel Four and Palace Films
results.brief_description: Full of surprises, this film did more than win extraordinary critical acclaim throughout the world. It upstaged the competition by receiving six Academy Award nominations and an Oscar for Best Screenplay. Set in Ireland, this spellbinding thriller involves a black British soldier, Jody (Forest Whittaker), who befriends his reluctant IRA captor, Fergus (Stephen Rea). When Jody is killed in an ambush, Fergus fulfills his dying wish - to find his girlfriend Dil (Jaye Davidson) in England. When Fergus and Dil become romantically involved, the crying game begins. Electrifying and seductive, this is the movie that had everyone talking. Also stars Miranda Richardson.
